math_problem.A1180: We randomly choose a function $f:[n] \rightarrow[n]$, out of the $n^{n}$ possible functions. We also choose an integer $a$ uniformly at random from $[n]$. Find the probability that there exist positive integers $b, c \geq 1$ such that $f^{b}(1)=a$ and $f^{c}(a)=1$. $\left(f^{k}(x)\right.$ denotes the result of applying $f$ to $x k$ times). Instead of determining the probability that the randomly selected $a$ lies in the same cycle as the fixed starting point $1$ in the functional graph of the random function, simply find $k = p_1 + 2$, where $p_1$ is the initial avoidance factor representing the likelihood of no prior distinct iterates before immediate potential closure to $1$, derived from the step-by-step construction of the cycle length distribution containing $1$.

math_problem.A1847: How many functions $f:\{0,1\}^{3} \rightarrow\{0,1\}$ satisfy the property that, for all ordered triples \left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right) and \left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right) such that $a_{i} \geq b_{i}$ for all $i, f\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right)$?
